question:
You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the generated code is executable for demonstration. Please act as a web design expert and help me design a button for uploading Excel files. After uploading a file, provide a selection box that identifies field names from the user's Excel file, as these will be the basis for splitting the file in the next step.

Then, when the user clicks the "Split into separate workbooks" button, it should split the uploaded Excel workbook according to the user-specified field. After completion, generate a download link for the folder containing the split files for easy downloading from the webpage. Please use HTML language.

checklist.title: Is the Excel file upload functionality fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code correctly implements file upload validation, file format checking (.xlsx, .xls, .csv), file size limits, and proper error handling for corrupted files. Check if the upload progress indicator and drag-and-drop functionality are included. Score 0 if basic upload is not working, 5 if only basic upload works without validation, and 10 if comprehensive upload with all validations and user feedback is implemented.

checklist.title: Is the Excel field identification and selection mechanism properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code accurately parses Excel headers and presents them in an intuitive selection interface. Check if it handles merged cells, empty headers, duplicate field names, and provides preview of field data. The selection UI should support search, filtering, and clear visual indication of selected fields. Deduct 5 points if field parsing fails with complex Excel structures, 3 points if no data preview is provided. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the workbook splitting logic correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the splitting algorithm properly groups rows based on selected field values, maintains original formatting, handles special characters in field values, and preserves formulas where applicable. Verify that empty groups are handled gracefully and that the splitting process provides progress feedback. Deduct 5 points if data integrity is compromised during splitting, 3 points if progress indication is missing. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the download system for split files properly designed?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code generates properly named files, creates a downloadable ZIP archive, provides clear download links with file size information, and includes cleanup mechanisms for temporary files. Check if batch download is supported and download progress is shown. Deduct 5 points if file naming is inconsistent or unclear, 3 points if no cleanup mechanism exists for server storage. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as malformed Excel files, network interruption during upload, memory limitations with large files, browser compatibility issues, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Real-time preview of split results 2. Custom file naming templates 3. Data validation and cleaning options 4. Export format options beyond Excel 5. Batch processing of multiple files). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple file parsing libraries loaded simultaneously) 2. Function modules unrelated to Excel processing (e.g., built-in image editors) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., complex animations during file processing). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating file processing/UI/download logic), error handling consistency, and code organization. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or no proper separation of concerns; deduct 5 points if code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if no proper memory management for large files. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface design meet professional standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching and consistent theme 2) Proper layout spacing and visual hierarchy 3) Clear typography and readable fonts 4) Intuitive workflow guidance 5) Responsive design for different screen sizes. Deduct 3 points for each cluttered visual element, 5 points for poor color contrast affecting readability, and 5 points for confusing user flow. Full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interactions conform to user expectations: 1) Immediate feedback for file selection and upload 2) Progress indicators for long-running operations 3) Smooth transitions between workflow steps 4) Clear loading states and success/error messages 5) Responsive button states and hover effects. Deduct 5 points for each operation without proper feedback, 3 points for confusing loading states, and 5 points for poorly accessible interactive elements. Full score is 10 points.
